contentrichtext.text: {{Taxobox | name = Wolf herrings | fossil_range = {{fossilrange|55|0}} <br>[[Eocene]] to Present<ref>{{cite journal | last = Sepkoski | first = Jack | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = A compendium of fossil marine animal genera | journal = Bulletins of American Paleontology | volume = 364 | issue = | pages = p.560 | publisher = | location = | year = 2002 | url = http://strata.ummp.lsa.umich.edu/jack/showgenera.php?taxon=611&rank=class | doi = | id = | accessdate = 2008-01-08 }}</ref> | image = Dorab wolf-herring.png | image_width = 200px | image_caption = ''[[Dorab wolf-herring]]'' | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Chordata]] | classis = [[Actinopterygii]] | ordo = [[Clupeiformes]] | familia = '''Chirocentridae''' | familia_authority = [[Georges Cuvier|Cuvier]] & [[Achille Valenciennes|Valenciennes]], 1846 | genus = '''''Chirocentrus''''' | genus_authority = [[Georges Cuvier|Cuvier]], 1816 | subdivision_ranks = [[Species]] | subdivision = See text }} The '''wolf herrings''' are a [[family (biology)|family]] ('''Chirocentridae''') of two marine species of [[ray-finned fish]] related to the [[herring]]s. Both species have elongated bodies and jaws with long sharp teeth that facilitate their ravenous appetites, mostly for other fish.<ref name=EoF>{{cite book |editor=Paxton, J.R. & Eschmeyer, W.N.|author= Nelson, Gareth|year=1998|title=Encyclopedia of Fishes|publisher= Academic Press|location=San Diego|page= 94|isbn= 0-12-547665-5}}</ref> Both species reach a length of 1 m. They have silvery sides and bluish backs. They are commercially fished, and marketed fresh or frozen. ==Species== * ''[[Chirocentrus dorab]]'' <small>([[Peter Forsskål|Forsskål]], 1775)</small> (Dorab wolf-herring) (found in warm coastal waters from the [[Red Sea]] to [[Japan]] and [[Australia]]) * ''[[Chirocentrus nudus]]'' <small>[[William John Swainson|Swainson]], 1839</small> (Whitefin wolf-herring) (found in a similar range) This species is difficult to distinguish from ''C. dorab'' (the former has a black mark on its [[dorsal fin]]). This species is also known to eat [[crab]]s in addition to its usual diet of smaller fish. ==References== {{reflist}} *{{FishBase_family|family=Chirocentridae|year=2011|month=June}} [[Category:Wolf herrings]] [[Category:Chirocentridae]] [[Category:Fish of the Pacific Ocean]] [[Category:Fish of the Indian Ocean]] {{Clupeiformes-stub}}
